posts.post_content: The cost isn't that expensive if you think about Bonfire's ideal targets. The only time you'd want to sweep the board is when there are many creatures, which often time are weenies with 1~2 toughness. Wildfire was a successful deck type utilizing heavy artifact mana and achieves 6+ mana by turn 2~4, the same could be applied here.

posts.post_content: This is an interesting one - I think it will basically be cast for its miracle cost whenever it can. There are few incentives to hold this card longer because it takes a lot of extra mana at most points to make more out of it and at the very least it's a [Blaze](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Blaze) on your opponent.

Posted By: djflo (4/27/2012 7:15:43 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Cards like this give mono-red a way to turn the game around even when the other side has stabalized its position, especially if your lucky enough to draw it late game. Adds another huge element of luck though if your running these cards, not the amount of luck I'm sure is appropriate in a magic game.  
  
Also this card is not strictly better then comet storm, in a multiplayer game you can kick comet storm to hit another player, you can't do that with this.

Posted By: steev (4/26/2012 6:00:53 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
NOT strictly better than Comet Storm. When are people going to learn how to differentiate "better in almost every situation" from "strictly better," the latter of which, in a game with thousands upon thousands upon thousands of changing pieces, seldom occurs, and moreover only seems appropriate because you've failed to consider every possible scenario.  
  
Just to give you a super cheesy counter example to your claim of strict superiority above, consider when you have a [Swans of Bryn Argoll](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swans of Bryn Argoll) in play and could benefit greatly from the possibility of directing damage at your own creature. In an ideal version of the above scenario, Comet Storm would give you a grip of cards and have the exact same net damage effect on your opponent.  
  
Even strict superiority claims for [Lightning Bolt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lightning Bolt) over [Shock](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Shock) reflect ignorance. Consider the case where you have 3 life and a [Near-Death Experience](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Near-Death Experience) on the battlefield, with one... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
NOT strictly better than Comet Storm. When are people going to learn how to differentiate "better in almost every situation" from "strictly better," the latter of which, in a game with thousands upon thousands upon thousands of changing pieces, seldom occurs, and moreover only seems appropriate because you've failed to consider every possible scenario.

Just to give you a super cheesy counter example to your claim of strict superiority above, consider when you have a Swans of Bryn Argoll in play and could benefit greatly from the possibility of directing damage at your own creature. In an ideal version of the above scenario, Comet Storm would give you a grip of cards and have the exact same net damage effect on your opponent.

Even strict superiority claims for Lightning Bolt over Shock reflect ignorance. Consider the case where you have 3 life and a Near-Death Experience on the battlefield, with one... (see all)

posts.post_content:
This card is broken in aggro vs. aggro. Giving aggro decks a one-sided wrath, even costing 5 to deal 2 damage, is huge. All mana dorks, huntmasters, tokens, geists... all dead with no repercusion on your side of the board. Even not-miracled, having or not having this card makes a huge difference, giving insane advantatge to those who can afford it.  
So, what can I say? I hate broken mythic cards.

Posted By: DarthParallax (5/14/2012 11:57:57 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
In limited, this has to be one of the most powerful cards ever printed. It wins you the game by burning them *and* clearing their blockers. Its a many-for-one. Its even splashable with the single {R} cost. I would never pass this card unless there was also a foil copy in the same pack.  
  
In constructed, it breaks open board stalls in creature mirrors. Even if your opponent has creatures big enough to survive it, they will likely have so much residual damage marked on them that they won't be able to block your smaller creatures without trading. I expect at the very least to see this in sideboards against decks full of small creatures (which is almost all of them in standard at the moment).  
  
Great art too. It looks like the Hammer of Dawn from Gears of War - complete with barbecued locust-zombies.
posts.html:

In constructed, it breaks open board stalls in creature mirrors. Even if your opponent has creatures big enough to survive it, they will likely have so much residual damage marked on them that they won't be able to block your smaller creatures without trading. I expect at the very least to see this in sideboards against decks full of small creatures (which is almost all of them in standard at the moment).

Great art too. It looks like the Hammer of Dawn from Gears of War - complete with barbecued locust-zombies.
